Stimulize User Manual 
Page 4 
INTRODUCTION 
Stimulize is a free web application designed to help behavioral scientists easily create and 
generate various trial-level paradigms that are compatible with the online survey platform, 
Qualtrics without any programming skills. Stimulize can generate classical sequential priming 
tasks, such as the Affective Misattribution Procedure, Implicit Association Test, and Go/No-go 
Task, as well as new paradigms developed by researchers. Acting as a toolkit, Stimulize allows 
researchers to easily mix and match common features of behavioral experiments to create custom 
paradigms. There are four key advantages that make Stimulize a preferable choice for researchers 
over other third-party software and applications for similar tasks: 
1.

e four key advantages that make Stimulize a preferable choice for researchers 
over other third-party software and applications for similar tasks: 
1. User-Friendly Interface: Stimulize offers an intuitive interface that allows researchers to 
design the necessary functions for their studies with minimal learning of the user manual. Frequently used features for behavioral science experiments are preprogrammed into 
easy, one-click buttons, enabling users to design experiments simply by toggling 
functions on or off. 2. Direct Compatibility for Online Studies: Experiments generated by Stimulize can be 
directly used for online studies. Stimulize produces files written in JavaScript, 
eliminating the need to convert code from other programming languages for online 
publication. 3.

es. Stimulize produces files written in JavaScript, 
eliminating the need to convert code from other programming languages for online 
publication. 3. Integration with Qualtrics but Stronger: Because Stimulize is compatible with 
Qualtrics, researchers can seamlessly import Stimulize-generated files into Qualtrics. This integration allows them to leverage both the advanced trial-level functions of 
Stimulize and the comprehensive survey features offered by Qualtrics. 4. Customization Flexibility: While Stimulize is easy to use for standard functions, it also 
allows more advanced researchers with programming skills to customize their 
experiments beyond the existing features. Customization can be done through the 
Stimulize interface or directly within the Qualtrics survey.

e their 
experiments beyond the existing features. Customization can be done through the 
Stimulize interface or directly within the Qualtrics survey. This flexibility caters to both 
researchers with standard experimental needs and those requiring more tailored designs.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 5 
Items, Stimuli, Pages, Trials, and Rounds 
 
It would be helpful for researchers to first understand how developers define “items,” 
“stimuli,” “pages,” “trials,” and “rounds” in Stimulize, then read the rest of User Manual. Items. BASIC FUNCTIONS 
Choose Stimulus Types 
 
Stimulize allows researchers to use both images and text as experiment stimuli. Researchers can select their preferred stimulus type by clicking the option on the right side of the 
Stimuli Pool panel. For image stimuli, researchers must first upload their images to an online server, such as 
the Qualtrics library, and obtain the URLs generated by the server. These URLs are unique links 
that provide access to the uploaded images.

such as 
the Qualtrics library, and obtain the URLs generated by the server. These URLs are unique links 
that provide access to the uploaded images. Once all images are uploaded and the corresponding 
URLs are obtained, researchers can input them into Stimulize and view the thumbnail images to 
ensure the stimuli are correctly placed and ordered for presentation. For text stimuli, researchers can directly type the text into the designated space in the 
middle of the Stimuli Pool panel. Text can be entered in any language (e.g., English, Chinese) as 
long as the browser recognizes it.

ed space in the 
middle of the Stimuli Pool panel. Text can be entered in any language (e.g., English, Chinese) as 
long as the browser recognizes it. After entering the text, researchers can customize the text style 
(e.g., size, color, bold, wrap-text) in the “Trial Block HTML” panel using the “Use 
Configurations” option, or opt for more advanced and personalized styling through the 
“Customize HTML” option in Stimulize. For detailed instructions, refer to the “PREVIEW AND 
FONT CUSTOMIZATION” section.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 6 
Add More Stimuli 
 
Stimulize allows researchers to add as many “Stimuli” tabs as needed in the “Stimuli 
Pool” panel. However, to generate an experiment file without errors, researchers must input at 
least one stimulus into Stimulize. Multiple “Stimuli” tabs (as shown in the screenshot above) are 
essential for many classic trial-level paradigms. For instance, a typical Affective Misattribution 
Procedure (AMP) task requires three “Stimuli” tabs to hold three different types of stimuli for 
each trial, such as primes, targets, and noise images. Stimuli Pool 
 
The number of items in each “Stimuli” tab can be easily added or deleted, as shown in the 
picture above.

, targets, and noise images. Stimuli Pool 
 
The number of items in each “Stimuli” tab can be easily added or deleted, as shown in the 
picture above. Researchers can add as many items as needed in each “Stimuli” tab by clicking 
“Add Item.” Items can also be deleted by clicking the red “bin” button. The order of items is 
important for researchers who prefer a fixed sequence rather than randomization. In Stimulize, 
stimuli are displayed in numerical order—item 2 follows item 1, item 3 follows item 2, and so 
on. Researchers can adjust the presentation order of the items using the “arrow” buttons on the 
right side of the “Stimuli Pool” panel.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 7 
Adjust Stimuli Number Counts 
 
Researchers can specify how many times an item should appear in the experiment by 
entering a number in the “Count” field, as shown in the picture above. For example, if “5” is 
entered for item 1 in the “Stimuli 1” tab, the item will be displayed a total of five times during 
the session when “Stimuli 1” is called in the experiment. Based on the preset order, the item may 
not appear consecutively five times but will follow the sequence of items until it has been 
displayed five times. Stimuli Randomization 
 
Randomizing the order of items in each “Stimuli” tab is a common feature and practice in 
behavioral science experiments.

es. Stimuli Randomization 
 
Randomizing the order of items in each “Stimuli” tab is a common feature and practice in 
behavioral science experiments. Stimulize includes a “Shuffle” function that allows researchers 
to easily randomize the order of items within the “Stimuli” tabs.1 When researchers activate the 
“Shuffle” function, Stimulize embeds JavaScript in the final output file to randomize the items 
 
1 We implemented the Fisher-Yates shuffle algorithm (Fisher & Yates, 1938) for our “Shuffle” function, as it is a 
standard method for generating a random permutation of a finite sequence. When researchers launch their survey 
with the experiment generated by Stimulize, each participant will receive a randomized order of the items displayed 
in each “Stimuli” tab.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 8 
and record the randomization order in the final Qualtrics survey for each participant. Each 
“Stimuli” tab has its own “Shuffle” button, which can be activated separately, allowing 
researchers to randomize the order of items in one tab while keeping the items in another tab in 
their original sequence.2 
 
“Restrict Max Repeat” Function. In some cases, researchers may want to prevent the 
same item from being repeated multiple times in succession. To do this, they can activate the 
“Restrict Max Repeat” function and specify the maximum number of consecutive repetitions 
allowed.

s in succession. To do this, they can activate the 
“Restrict Max Repeat” function and specify the maximum number of consecutive repetitions 
allowed. For example, if “2” is entered, a stimulus cannot appear more than twice in a row.3 
 
Load, Save, Use Example Settings 
 
 
Save & Load Functions 
Stimulize allows researchers to save and download their designed configurations or 
example settings, with all parameters stored in a JSON file, by simply clicking the “Save” button 
at the top right of the web app. At the top right of the web app, there is also a “Load” button that 
 
2 We recommend you activate the “Shuffle” function for full randomization.

app. At the top right of the web app, there is also a “Load” button that 
 
2 We recommend you activate the “Shuffle” function for full randomization. If you do not open the “Shuffle” 
function, the item display will follow the numerical order (e.g., Stimuli 1: Item 1 à Item 2 à Item 3 à Item 4 à 
Item 1). 3 However, researchers should ensure that the number specified in the “Restrict Max Repeat” function is feasible. For instance, if a “Stimuli” tab has one item set to appear 2 times and another set to appear 20 times, restricting 
repeats to “2” may be unachievable. In such cases, the prewritten code will attempt to shuffle the order up to 100 
times and then stop, providing the randomization result from the 100th attempt.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 9 
allows researchers to upload JSON files from other Stimulize users to view or modify their 
settings. This practice is encouraged to facilitate collaboration and promote open science. Use Example Settings 
 
Stimulize provides sample settings and corresponding Qualtrics surveys to give 
researchers a general idea of the types of experiments that can be designed and generated using 
the web app. These examples are typically drawn from published journal articles and recent 
manuscripts in preparation. However, the availability of these examples does not limit 
Stimulize's capabilities to just these classic experiments. You can design and generate entirely 
new experiments using Stimulize.

les does not limit 
Stimulize's capabilities to just these classic experiments. You can design and generate entirely 
new experiments using Stimulize. If you publish a paper using tasks created with Stimulize, we 
encourage you to share your Stimulize settings by sending us your JSON file. We will feature 
your setting in the "Use Example Settings" section.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 10 
PRIMING FUNCTION 
 
 The “Priming” function is one of the key advanced features offered by Stimulize. As the 
name suggests, it is designed for researchers who need to manipulate one or more items from a 
“Stimuli Pool” to be used as priming stimuli. This is a common practice in behavioral science 
research, where researchers intentionally highlight certain stimuli (or manipulate the frequency 
of these stimuli) to make them more salient or noticeable to participants—often unconsciously—
compared to other stimuli presented in a sequence. Set up Your Target Stimuli 
 
By activating the “Priming” button, researchers can set up a target stimulus.

to other stimuli presented in a sequence. Set up Your Target Stimuli 
 
By activating the “Priming” button, researchers can set up a target stimulus. They need 
to: (1) name the target stimulus (the name can be chosen freely, but it will be used as part of the 
embedded data for calling out the item), (2) add candidate stimuli to the "Included items" 
section, (3) select as many items as desired as candidates for the target stimulus. During the 
survey, one of the selected items will be randomly chosen as the target stimulus for each 
participant, and (4) select as many items as they wish for exclusion. To prevent potential errors, 
Stimulize automatically ensures that an item cannot be included and excluded simultaneously.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 11 
Example. In the settings shown above, researchers chose all the items in Stimuli 1, so 
each had a quarter chance to become Target_1 in the “Stimuli 1.” 
 
 
Stimulize does not limit the number of target stimuli in one "Stimuli Pool," as long as 
there are enough items to serve as candidates. As shown above, researchers can continue adding 
more target stimuli by selecting an item (e.g., Control_1) and including all the items in "Stimuli 
1" except the one chosen as Target_1, using the "Excluded items" function. Note. Researchers must activate the "Priming" function separately for each "Stimuli 
Pool" if they want to set up target stimuli in different pools. Present Randomly Selected Target Stimuli in Qualtrics Survey.

ately for each "Stimuli 
Pool" if they want to set up target stimuli in different pools. Present Randomly Selected Target Stimuli in Qualtrics Survey. In some experiments, 
researchers may want to present the randomly selected target stimuli before or after the main 
tasks in the survey to manipulate the target and measure participants' focus of interest. In such 
cases, researchers can display the target stimuli in their Qualtrics survey by embedding the 
stimulus content name (found by clicking the small question mark at the top right of the "Name" 
field), such as “prime_stimuli_2_Name_content,” into a standard Qualtrics block.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 12 
Changing Number Counts of Target Stimuli in Different Rounds of the Designed Tasks 
 
 
In some experiments, researchers may want to present the target stimulus (e.g., Target_1) 
more frequently than the other unselected stimuli. They can use the "Override Stimuli Count" 
function to adjust the number of times the target stimulus is displayed. As shown in the example setting above, the original count for all items in Stimuli 1 is 5. The researcher wanted the selected target stimulus (Target_1) to appear 20 times as Stimuli 1 in 
Round 1, 30 times in Round 2, and 5 times in Round 3, so they configured the settings 
accordingly. Note. Researchers need to indicate the number counts separately for their selected items 
in each stimulus.

they configured the settings 
accordingly. Note. Researchers need to indicate the number counts separately for their selected items 
in each stimulus. See the “Add More Rounds” section for the meaning of “Round.”

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 13 
CONCURRENT STIMULI DISPLAY 
 
Concurrent stimuli display is another key feature offered by Stimulize, allowing 
researchers to display multiple stimuli from different stimuli pools on the same display page of a 
trial. After activating the concurrent display function, researchers will see the timeline color 
change from "blue" to "orange," and the label will switch from "Stimuli" to "Display." They can 
then insert multiple stimuli into a single display page by clicking the small "pencil" icon on the 
right of each display page. Additionally, researchers can add as many display pages as needed in 
the trial flow once the concurrent stimuli display is enabled.

ach display page. Additionally, researchers can add as many display pages as needed in 
the trial flow once the concurrent stimuli display is enabled. As shown above, when researchers click the small “pencil” icon, a window will pop up, 
allowing them to add more stimuli both horizontally and vertically. For each stimulus, 
researchers should specify the stimuli pool from which the items will be drawn. For an example, 
please refer to the preview image below:

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 14

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 15 
BETWEEN-PAGES ADVANCED LOGIC 
 
 
One of the most advanced features offered by Stimulize is its between-pages advanced 
logic. Instead of simply presenting stimuli/pages in a fixed order, this function allows researchers 
to specify the conditions under which a stimulus appears by setting display logic. To begin, researchers must switch Stimulize from "Simple" mode to "Advanced" mode 
and add as many pages as needed for each trial.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 16 
 
When researchers include more than one page in each trial, they can specify the display 
logic by activating the logic function. For example, as shown below, the researcher indicated that 
Page #1 displays stimuli from "Stimuli Pool1" and accepts "d" and "k" as responses or 
automatically proceeds to the next page after 1000 milliseconds (1 second). They can then set the 
display logic for Page #2 so that it only appears if the response to Page #1 is "d." In this case, 
Page #1 would continue to Page #2. Note: Similar to concurrent stimuli display, once you activate between-pages advance 
logic, you can still use concurrent display and other advanced functions, allowing for greater 
flexibility in your experiment design.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 17

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 18 
SPECIAL SETTINGS 
Trial Timeline 
 
In both the sample and advanced modes, Stimulize allows researchers to customize the 
experiment timeline through a user-friendly interface. Researchers can easily set the duration in 
milliseconds for each stimulus presentation, the interval between stimuli, the delay before 
receiving a response, and the delay after receiving the response (for more on advanced mode, see 
the "Advanced Logic" section). As verified in the supplementary materials of the main 
manuscript, all time durations are highly accurate and precise. Number of Total Trials 
 
 
Researchers must specify the total number of trials in each round of their experiment. This number should match or be less than the total count of items in each stimulus.

cify the total number of trials in each round of their experiment. This number should match or be less than the total count of items in each stimulus. If the total 
number of trials exceeds a stimulus's count, the stimulus may appear blank after all items have 
been used up. Additionally, if the number of trials does not align with the number of stimuli in

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 19 
the pools, the system will issue a warning about the potential error caused by the mismatch 
between trials and stimuli. Add More Rounds 
 
Researchers who want to include more than one round of experiment for their research 
purpose can turn on the bottom “Add more rounds”. In such cases, they can include more than 
one round of experiments in their research and add other study materials (e.g., instructions， 
survey questions, and manipulation materials) between the different rounds of the experiment.

arch and add other study materials (e.g., instructions， 
survey questions, and manipulation materials) between the different rounds of the experiment. For example, in some experiments, researchers aim to measure participants’ attitude change after 
receiving certain primed information using another round of the experiment to test if the new 
stimulus can influence the existing attitudes formed in the first round. As the note written below the “Add more rounds” activation button, researchers also need 
to copy and paste the “trial” block in their Qualtrics survey to ensure all indicated rounds are 
fully presented. See below for the step illustration in Qualtrics

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 20 
 
As shown in the settings above, since the researcher specified “3” rounds, they will need 
to copy the “Run trials” block in the Qualtrics survey twice, resulting in a total of three “Run 
trials” blocks. The order of the three “Run trials” blocks will not impact the researcher’s experiment. As 
shown below, the researcher may put as many regular Qualtrics blocks as they want between the 
“Run trials” blocks.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 21 
 
 
Allowed Input Keys 
 
 
Since many behavioral experiments require participants to respond by pressing keyboard 
buttons, Stimulize allows researchers to use a range of response keys, including letter keys (a–z, 
case insensitive), number keys (0–9), arrow keys (left, right, up, down), the space bar, and the 
enter key. Author notes: The data file records participants’ key input. For example, if you indicate 
“d” and “k” as your allowed input keys, then you will see “d” and “k” appear in your data 
recordings.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 22 
Auto Proceed to Next Trial After Timeout 
 
In some experiments, researchers treat participants’ inaction as a kind of response (e.g., 
Go/No-go Task; holding from pressing a key or simply viewing trials on display.) or want 
participants to move to the next trial after certain durations. In those cases, researchers need to 
activate the “Auto Proceed to Next Trial After Timeout” function to allow their paradigm to 
continue to the next trial without receiving a key input from their participants. Otherwise, 
participants won’t be able to proceed unless they press the keys.

to the next trial without receiving a key input from their participants. Otherwise, 
participants won’t be able to proceed unless they press the keys. After researchers activate the “Auto Proceed to Next Trial After Timeout” function, they 
need to indicate the time length for the paradigm to auto-proceed to the subsequent trial (in 
milliseconds).

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 23 
PREVIEW AND FONT CUSTOMIZATION 
 
Stimulize allows researchers to customize the size of image stimuli and the font (e.g., 
size, color, bold) of text stimuli. Researchers can also preview the appearance of the stimuli. Customize Image Size 
 
 
By opening the “Trial Block HTML,” researchers can specify the size and placement of 
their image stimuli. We recommend maintaining the original width-to-height ratio when resizing 
the images to ensure consistent scaling. Customize Text Style (i.e., size, color, bold) 
 
Stimulize enables researchers to customize the font of their textual stimuli (i.e., size, 
bold, color).

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 24 
 
Instruction Text 
 
Researchers can add instructions to the trials, which will be displayed directly below the 
stimuli items. For example, in some paradigms, researchers include instructions such as “d = less 
pleasant; k = more pleasant” to remind participants which keys to press after each trial. Preview Trials 
 
 
Researchers can preview each of their stimuli items using the preview function.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 25 
DATA COLLECTION AND RECORDING FORMAT 
 Experiment surveys generated by Stimulize automatically include four variables: shuffle 
results (“shuffleResult”), response answers (“sptResponses”), response/reaction time 
(“sptResponseDurations”), and prime results (if applicable, “primeResult”) in the Qualtrics data 
output. Sequential Priming Paradigm Results 
 
Participants’ responses to the trials in the sequential priming paradigms are recorded 
under the variable named “sptResponses.” All responses for a sequential priming paradigm 
(regardless of the number of rounds it includes) are recorded into one variable, which is 
presented as a sequence of key inputs.

al priming paradigm 
(regardless of the number of rounds it includes) are recorded into one variable, which is 
presented as a sequence of key inputs. For example, if a sequential priming paradigm has 20 
trials for two rounds and the allowed key inputs are “d” and “k,” then the sequential priming 
paradigm results (“sptResponses”) of each participant should include 40 letters (either d or k) 
listed in a sequence. The results of two rounds are separated using a semicolon (“;”). Shuffle Results (aka.

hould include 40 letters (either d or k) 
listed in a sequence. The results of two rounds are separated using a semicolon (“;”). Shuffle Results (aka. Randomization results) 
 
 
The stimulus item randomization results are recorded as “shuffleResult.” The Stimulize 
uses “/” to separate the randomization results for different rounds of sequential priming 
paradigms and uses “;” to separate the items from different stimuli in a round of the sequential 
priming paradigm. The number here represents the item number.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 26 
Response/Reaction Time 
 
Participants’ response/reaction time is recorded as “sptResponseDurations.” All the 
numbers present the time that the participant spends to give their answer in a trial. For example, 
the first number in the example above is 902. It means that this participant spends 902 
milliseconds indicating their answer for Round 1 Trial 1. Again, the response/reaction time lists 
are separated by a semicolon (“;”) between two rounds. Priming Results 
 
If researchers activate the “Priming” function, the result of the function will be recorded 
in the variable called “primeResult.” The resulting name is formed as a combination of the 
stimulus number and the named selected item.

be recorded 
in the variable called “primeResult.” The resulting name is formed as a combination of the 
stimulus number and the named selected item. For example, in the data above, we see that the 
system randomly selects Item 1 as Target_1 in Stimuli 1 and Item 2 as Control_1 in Stimuli 1 for 
this participant.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 27 
SYSTEM PRE-CHECKS 
 
Trial Number Checks 
 
Stimulize Check 1: 
 
Stimulize automatically generates the potential total item counts in each round of the 
experiment task. It is calculated based on the number of counts researchers put for each item in 
the Stimuli Pool and the number they indicate in the priming function (if applicable). Check 1 
helps researchers determine the number of total trials they want to indicate in the “Number of 
total trials” function. Stimulize Check 2: 
 
Stimulize checks and reminds researchers if their indicated number of total trials matches 
the total item counts of each stimulus (Check 2). Suppose a warning shows that the number of 
trials is larger than the total item counts of the stimuli.

total item counts of each stimulus (Check 2). Suppose a warning shows that the number of 
trials is larger than the total item counts of the stimuli. In that case, Stimulize may still allow 
researchers to generate experiment surveys in the current setting, but the sequential priming 
paradigms in the surveys might include some errors. For example, later trials of the sequential 
priming paradigms may show blanks because all the items are used up. Internal Loading Check 
 
An internal loading check, written in JavaScript, ensures that all image stimuli are fully 
loaded before the task begins. If the loading process is incomplete, the check will hide the

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 28 
"Continue" button, preventing participants from entering a task that hasn't fully loaded, which 
could compromise the accuracy of the research.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 29 
Generate Surveys and Upload Them to Qualtrics 
 
After completing all the settings on the Stimulize, researchers can click “Generate 
Qualtrics qsf File” to download their experiment files! Then, researchers log in to their Qualtrics 
account and upload the qsf file to have the experiment surveys prepared in their Qualtrics 
account.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 30 
Tips about Modifying the Generated Experiment Surveys 
 
A Stimulize-generated experiment survey includes the “Load parameters” block and the 
“Run trials” block. All the code is written in JavaScript; researchers do not need to modify 
anything here.

Stimulize User Manual 
Page 31 
Tips about Modifying the Embedded Data 
 
 
We recommend researchers not change the experiment settings through the embedded 
data, although it is possible to do so. Researchers may add their own embedded data in Qualtrics 
as long as the names of the new embedded data do not repeat the existing ones.

INTRODUCTION

Stimulize is a free web application designed to help behavioral scientists easily create and
generate various trial-level paradigms that are compatible with the online survey platform,
Qualtrics without any programming skills. Stimulize can generate classical sequential priming
tasks, such as the Affective Misattribution Procedure, Implicit Association Test, and Go/No-go
Task, as well as new paradigms developed by researchers. Acting as a toolkit, Stimulize allows
researchers to easily mix and match common features of behavioral experiments to create custom
paradigms. There are four key advantages that make Stimulize a preferable choice for researchers
over other third-party software and applications for similar tasks:

1.

re four key advantages that make Stimulize a preferable choice for researchers
over other third-party software and applications for similar tasks:

1. User-Friendly Interface: Stimulize offers an intuitive interface that allows researchers to
design the necessary functions for their studies with minimal learning of the user manual. Frequently used features for behavioral science experiments are preprogrammed into
easy, one-click buttons, enabling users to design experiments simply by toggling
functions on or off. 2. Direct Compatibility for Online Studies: Experiments generated by Stimulize can be
directly used for online studies. Stimulize produces files written in JavaScript,
eliminating the need to convert code from other programming languages for online
publication. 3.

dies. Stimulize produces files written in JavaScript,
eliminating the need to convert code from other programming languages for online
publication. 3. Integration with Qualtrics but Stronger: Because Stimulize is compatible with
Qualtrics, researchers can seamlessly import Stimulize-generated files into Qualtrics. This integration allows them to leverage both the advanced trial-level functions of
Stimulize and the comprehensive survey features offered by Qualtrics. 4. Customization Flexibility: While Stimulize is easy to use for standard functions, it also
allows more advanced researchers with programming skills to customize their
experiments beyond the existing features. Customization can be done through the
Stimulize interface or directly within the Qualtrics survey.

Items, Stimuli, Pages, Trials, and Rounds

It would be helpful for researchers to first understand how developers define “items,”
“stimuli,” “pages,” “trials,” and “rounds” in Stimulize, then read the rest of User Manual. Items. BASIC FUNCTIONS

Stimulize allows researchers to use both images and text as experiment stimuli. Researchers can select their preferred stimulus type by clicking the option on the right side of the
Stimuli Pool panel.

d text as experiment stimuli. Researchers can select their preferred stimulus type by clicking the option on the right side of the
Stimuli Pool panel. For image stimuli, researchers must first upload their images to an online server, such as
the Qualtrics library, and obtain the URLs generated by the server. These URLs are unique links
that provide access to the uploaded images. Once all images are uploaded and the corresponding
URLs are obtained, researchers can input them into Stimulize and view the thumbnail images to
ensure the stimuli are correctly placed and ordered for presentation. For text stimuli, researchers can directly type the text into the designated space in the
middle of the Stimuli Pool panel.

ordered for presentation. For text stimuli, researchers can directly type the text into the designated space in the
middle of the Stimuli Pool panel. Text can be entered in any language (e.g., English, Chinese) as
long as the browser recognizes it. After entering the text, researchers can customize the text style
(e.g., size, color, bold, wrap-text) in the “Trial Block HTML” panel using the “Use
Configurations” option, or opt for more advanced and personalized styling through the
“Customize HTML” option in Stimulize. For detailed instructions, refer to the “PREVIEW AND
FONT CUSTOMIZATION?” section.

The number of items in each “Stimuli” tab can be easily added or deleted, as shown in the

picture above.

Add more items for the current stimuli pool

The number of items in each “Stimuli” tab can be easily added or deleted, as shown in the

picture above. Researchers can add as many items as needed in each “Stimuli” tab by clicking

“Add Item.” Items can also be deleted by clicking the red “bin” button. The order of items is

important for researchers who prefer a fixed sequence rather than randomization. In Stimulize,

stimuli are displayed in numerical order—item 2 follows item 1, item 3 follows item 2, and so

on. Researchers can adjust the presentation order of the items using the “arrow” buttons on the

right side of the “Stimuli Pool” panel.

presentation order

Randomizing the order of items in each “Stimuli” tab is a common feature and practice in
behavioral science experiments.

ndomized

presentation order

Randomizing the order of items in each “Stimuli” tab is a common feature and practice in
behavioral science experiments. Stimulize includes a “Shuffle” function that allows researchers
to easily randomize the order of items within the “Stimuli” tabs.! When researchers activate the

“Shuffle” function, Stimulize embeds JavaScript in the final output file to randomize the items

' We implemented the Fisher-Yates shuffle algorithm (Fisher & Yates, 1938) for our “Shuffle” function, as it is a
standard method for generating a random permutation of a finite sequence. When researchers launch their survey
with the experiment generated by Stimulize, each participant will receive a randomized order of the items displayed
in each “Stimuli” tab.

and record the randomization order in the final Qualtrics survey for each participant. Each
“Stimuli” tab has its own “Shuffle” button, which can be activated separately, allowing
researchers to randomize the order of items in one tab while keeping the items in another tab in
their original sequence.”

“Restrict Max Repeat” Function. In some cases, researchers may want to prevent the
same item from being repeated multiple times in succession. To do this, they can activate the
“Restrict Max Repeat” function and specify the maximum number of consecutive repetitions

allowed. For example, if “2” is entered, a stimulus cannot appear more than twice in a row.*

Save & Load Functions

Stimulize allows researchers to save and download their designed configurations or
example settings, with all parameters stored in a JSON file, by simply clicking the “Save” button
at the top right of the web app.

d configurations or
example settings, with all parameters stored in a JSON file, by simply clicking the “Save” button
at the top right of the web app. At the top right of the web app, there is also a “Load” button that

* We recommend you activate the “Shuffle” function for full randomization. If you do not open the “Shuffle”
function, the item display will follow the numerical order (e.g., Stimuli 1: Item 1 > Item 2 > Item 3 > Item 4 >
Item 1). > However, researchers should ensure that the number specified in the “Restrict Max Repeat” function is feasible. For instance, if a “Stimuli” tab has one item set to appear 2 times and another set to appear 20 times, restricting
repeats to “2” may be unachievable.

or instance, if a “Stimuli” tab has one item set to appear 2 times and another set to appear 20 times, restricting
repeats to “2” may be unachievable. In such cases, the prewritten code will attempt to shuffle the order up to 100
times and then stop, providing the randomization result from the 100th attempt.

allows researchers to upload JSON files from other Stimulize users to view or modify their

settings. This practice is encouraged to facilitate collaboration and promote open science. Use Example Settings

Stimulize provides sample settings and corresponding Qualtrics surveys to give
researchers a general idea of the types of experiments that can be designed and generated using
the web app. These examples are typically drawn from published journal articles and recent
manuscripts in preparation. However, the availability of these examples does not limit
Stimulize's capabilities to just these classic experiments. You can design and generate entirely
new experiments using Stimulize.

mples does not limit
Stimulize's capabilities to just these classic experiments. You can design and generate entirely
new experiments using Stimulize. If you publish a paper using tasks created with Stimulize, we
encourage you to share your Stimulize settings by sending us your JSON file. We will feature

your setting in the "Use Example Settings" section.

PRIMING FUNCTION
The “Priming” function is one of the key advanced features offered by Stimulize. As the
name suggests, it is designed for researchers who need to manipulate one or more items from a
“Stimuli Pool” to be used as priming stimuli. This is a common practice in behavioral science
research, where researchers intentionally highlight certain stimuli (or manipulate the frequency
of these stimuli) to make them more salient or noticeable to participants—often unconsciously—

compared to other stimuli presented in a sequence. Set up Your Target Stimuli

By activating the “Priming” button, researchers can set up a target stimulus.

Possible total items count: 35

By activating the “Priming” button, researchers can set up a target stimulus. They need
to: (1) name the target stimulus (the name can be chosen freely, but it will be used as part of the
embedded data for calling out the item), (2) add candidate stimuli to the "Included items"
section, (3) select as many items as desired as candidates for the target stimulus. During the
survey, one of the selected items will be randomly chosen as the target stimulus for each
participant, and (4) select as many items as they wish for exclusion. To prevent potential errors,

Stimulize automatically ensures that an item cannot be included and excluded simultaneously.

Example. In the settings shown above, researchers chose all the items in Stimuli 1, so

each had a quarter chance to become Target_1 in the “Stimuli 1.”

Stimulize does not limit the number of target stimuli in one "Stimuli Pool," as long as
there are enough items to serve as candidates. As shown above, researchers can continue adding
more target stimuli by selecting an item (e.g., Control_1) and including all the items in "Stimuli
1" except the one chosen as Target_1, using the "Excluded items" function. Note. Researchers must activate the "Priming" function separately for each "Stimuli
Pool" if they want to set up target stimuli in different pools.

n. Note. Researchers must activate the "Priming" function separately for each "Stimuli
Pool" if they want to set up target stimuli in different pools. Present Randomly Selected Target Stimuli in Qualtrics Survey. In some experiments,
researchers may want to present the randomly selected target stimuli before or after the main
tasks in the survey to manipulate the target and measure participants' focus of interest. In such
cases, researchers can display the target stimuli in their Qualtrics survey by embedding the
stimulus content name (found by clicking the small question mark at the top right of the "Name"

field), such as “prime stimuli 2 Name content,” into a standard Qualtrics block.

In some experiments, researchers may want to present the target stimulus (e.g., Target_1)

function to adjust the number of times the target stimulus is displayed. As shown in the example setting above, the original count for all items in Stimuli 1 is 5. The researcher wanted the selected target stimulus (Target_1) to appear 20 times as Stimuli | in

accordingly. Note. Researchers need to indicate the number counts separately for their selected items

in each stimulus. See the “Add More Rounds” section for the meaning of “Round.”

BETWEEN-PAGES ADVANCED LOGIC

One of the most advanced features offered by Stimulize is its between-pages advanced
logic. Instead of simply presenting stimuli/pages in a fixed order, this function allows researchers
to specify the conditions under which a stimulus appears by setting display logic. To begin, researchers must switch Stimulize from "Simple" mode to "Advanced" mode

and add as many pages as needed for each trial. Switching from the “Simple” mode

When researchers include more than one page in each trial, they can specify the display
logic by activating the logic function. For example, as shown below, the researcher indicated that
Page #1 displays stimuli from "Stimuli Pooll" and accepts "d" and "k" as responses or
automatically proceeds to the next page after 1000 milliseconds (1 second).

plays stimuli from "Stimuli Pooll" and accepts "d" and "k" as responses or
automatically proceeds to the next page after 1000 milliseconds (1 second). They can then set the
display logic for Page #2 so that it only appears if the response to Page #1 is "d." In this case,
Page #1 would continue to Page #2. Note: Similar to concurrent stimuli display, once you activate between-pages advance
logic, you can still use concurrent display and other advanced functions, allowing for greater

flexibility in your experiment design.

the initiation of the following trials. In both the sample and advanced modes, Stimulize allows researchers to customize the
experiment timeline through a user-friendly interface. Researchers can easily set the duration in
milliseconds for each stimulus presentation, the interval between stimuli, the delay before
receiving a response, and the delay after receiving the response (for more on advanced mode, see
the "Advanced Logic" section). As verified in the supplementary materials of the main

manuscript, all time durations are highly accurate and precise.

the "Advanced Logic" section). As verified in the supplementary materials of the main

manuscript, all time durations are highly accurate and precise. Number of Total Trials

Number of total trials

Indicate the number of trials for your

20 trials <— arn :
sequential priming paradigm. Researchers must specify the total number of trials in each round of their experiment. This number should match or be less than the total count of items in each stimulus. If the total
number of trials exceeds a stimulus's count, the stimulus may appear blank after all items have

been used up. Additionally, if the number of trials does not align with the number of stimuli in

the pools, the system will issue a warning about the potential error caused by the mismatch

between trials and stimuli. Add More Rounds

Researchers who want to include more than one round of experiment for their research

purpose can turn on the bottom “Add more rounds”. In such cases, they can include more than

one round of experiments in their research and add other study materials (e.g., instructions °

survey questions, and manipulation materials) between the different rounds of the experiment.

rch and add other study materials (e.g., instructions °

survey questions, and manipulation materials) between the different rounds of the experiment. For example, in some experiments, researchers aim to measure participants’ attitude change after
receiving certain primed information using another round of the experiment to test if the new
stimulus can influence the existing attitudes formed in the first round. As the note written below the “Add more rounds” activation button, researchers also need
to copy and paste the “trial” block in their Qualtrics survey to ensure all indicated rounds are

fully presented. See below for the step illustration in Qualtrics

Since many behavioral experiments require participants to respond by pressing keyboard

buttons, Stimulize allows researchers to use a range of response keys, including letter keys (a—z,

case insensitive), number keys (0-9), arrow keys (left, right, up, down), the space bar, and the

enter key.

sponse keys, including letter keys (a—z,

case insensitive), number keys (0-9), arrow keys (left, right, up, down), the space bar, and the

enter key. Author notes: The data file records participants’ key input. For example, if you indicate

“d” and “k” as your allowed input keys, then you will see “d” and “k” appear in your data

recordings.

. @) Auto proceed to next trial after timeout 1000 ms

In some experiments, researchers treat participants’ inaction as a kind of response (e.g.,
Go/No-go Task; holding from pressing a key or simply viewing trials on display.) or want
participants to move to the next trial after certain durations. In those cases, researchers need to
activate the “Auto Proceed to Next Trial After Timeout” function to allow their paradigm to
continue to the next trial without receiving a key input from their participants.

eed to Next Trial After Timeout” function to allow their paradigm to
continue to the next trial without receiving a key input from their participants. Otherwise,
participants won’t be able to proceed unless they press the keys. After researchers activate the “Auto Proceed to Next Trial After Timeout” function, they
need to indicate the time length for the paradigm to auto-proceed to the subsequent trial (in

milliseconds).

DATA COLLECTION AND RECORDING FORMAT
Experiment surveys generated by Stimulize automatically include four variables: shuffle
results (“shuffleResult’”), response answers (“sptResponses’’), response/reaction time
(“‘sptResponseDurations’”’), and prime results (if applicable, “primeResult”) in the Qualtrics data

output.

(“sptResponses’’), response/reaction time
(“‘sptResponseDurations’”’), and prime results (if applicable, “primeResult”) in the Qualtrics data

output. Sequential Priming Paradigm Results

 sptResponses

k,k,d,k,k,k,k,k,d,k,k,k,k,k,k,k,k,k,d,k,k,k,k,k,d,k,k,k,k,

Participants’ responses to the trials in the sequential priming paradigms are recorded

under the variable named “sptResponses.” All responses for a sequential priming paradigm
(regardless of the number of rounds it includes) are recorded into one variable, which is
presented as a sequence of key inputs.

tial priming paradigm
(regardless of the number of rounds it includes) are recorded into one variable, which is
presented as a sequence of key inputs. For example, if a sequential priming paradigm has 20
trials for two rounds and the allowed key inputs are “d” and “k,” then the sequential priming
paradigm results (“‘sptResponses”’) of each participant should include 40 letters (either d or k)

listed in a sequence. The results of two rounds are separated using a semicolon (“3”). Shuffle Results (aka.

rent rounds of sequential priming

paradigms and uses “;” to separate the items from different stimuli in a round of the sequential

priming paradigm. The number here represents the item number.

Response/Reaction Time

Participants’ response/reaction time is recorded as “‘sptResponseDurations.” All the
numbers present the time that the participant spends to give their answer in a trial. For example,
the first number in the example above is 902. It means that this participant spends 902
milliseconds indicating their answer for Round 1 Trial 1.

the first number in the example above is 902. It means that this participant spends 902
milliseconds indicating their answer for Round 1 Trial 1. Again, the response/reaction time lists

66,99

are separated by a semicolon (“;”) between two rounds. Priming Results

primeResult

stimuli_1_Target_1=1;stimuli_1_Control_1=2
If researchers activate the “Priming” function, the result of the function will be recorded
in the variable called “primeResult.” The resulting name is formed as a combination of the
stimulus number and the named selected item. For example, in the data above, we see that the
system randomly selects Item 1 as Target_1 in Stimuli 1 and Item 2 as Control_1 in Stimuli | for

this participant.

SYSTEM PRE-CHECKS
Trial Number Checks

Stimulize Check 1:

Possible total items count: The SP-Builder automatically

e Round1:50 <————é generates possible total items counts

e Round 2: 60 in each stimuli. Stimulize automatically generates the potential total item counts in each round of the
experiment task. It is calculated based on the number of counts researchers put for each item in
the Stimuli Pool and the number they indicate in the priming function (if applicable). Check 1
helps researchers determine the number of total trials they want to indicate in the “Number of

total trials” function. Stimulize Check 2:

The SP-Builder automatically checks
if the indicated “number of total
trials” matches the total item counts

Number of total trials of each stimulus.

The SP-Builder automatically checks
if the indicated “number of total
trials” matches the total item counts

Number of total trials of each stimulus. 30 trials |
@ The Number of Total Trials is larger than the Total Items Count of stimuli 2, which is 20

@ The Number of Total Trials is larger than the Total Items Count of stimuli 3, which is 20

Stimulize checks and reminds researchers if their indicated number of total trials matches
the total item counts of each stimulus (Check 2). Suppose a warning shows that the number of
trials is larger than the total item counts of the stimuli. In that case, Stimulize may still allow
researchers to generate experiment surveys in the current setting, but the sequential priming
paradigms in the surveys might include some errors.

llow
researchers to generate experiment surveys in the current setting, but the sequential priming
paradigms in the surveys might include some errors. For example, later trials of the sequential

priming paradigms may show blanks because all the items are used up. Internal Loading Check
An internal loading check, written in JavaScript, ensures that all image stimuli are fully

loaded before the task begins. If the loading process is incomplete, the check will hide the

"Continue" button, preventing participants from entering a task that hasn't fully loaded, which

could compromise the accuracy of the research.

After completing all the settings on the Stimulize, researchers can click “Generate

Qualtrics qsf File” to download their experiment files! Then, researchers log in to their Qualtrics

account and upload the qsf file to have the experiment surveys prepared in their Qualtrics

account.

Add Block

A Stimulize-generated experiment survey includes the “Load parameters” block and the
“Run trials” block. All the code is written in JavaScript; researchers do not need to modify

anything here.

We recommend researchers not change the experiment settings through the embedded
data, although it is possible to do so. Researchers may add their own embedded data in Qualtrics

as long as the names of the new embedded data do not repeat the existing ones.
